description: Enterprise techniques used by Dragonfly 2.0, ATT&CK group G0074 v1.0
name: Dragonfly 2.0 (G0074)

techniques.comment: [Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) created accounts disguised as legitimate backup and service accounts as well as an email administration account.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used batch scripts to enumerate administrators in the environment.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) has used various forms of spearphishing in attempts to get users to open links or attachments.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used command line for execution.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used SMB for C2.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) created accounts on victims, including administrator accounts, some of which appeared to be tailored to each individual staging target.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) has disabled host-based firewalls. The group has also globally opened port 3389.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) modified the Registry to perform multiple techniques through the use of [Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075).

[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) has injected SMB URLs into malicious Word spearphishing attachments to initiate [Forced Authentication](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1187).
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) accessed email accounts using Outlook Web Access.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) compromised legitimate organizations' websites to create watering holes to compromise victims.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) dropped and executed SecretsDump and CrackMapExec, tools that can dump password hashes.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) likely obtained a list of hosts in the victim environment.

[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) cleared Windows event logs and other logs produced by tools they used, including system, security, terminal services, remote services, and audit logs. The actors also deleted specific Registry keys.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used scheduled tasks to automatically log out of created accounts every 8 hours as well as to execute malicious files.

[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) identified and browsed file servers in the victim network, sometimes , viewing files pertaining to ICS or Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used a batch script to gather folder and file names from victim hosts.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) compromised user credentials and used valid accounts for operations.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) collected data from local victim systems.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) queried the Registry to identify victim information.

[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) has gathered hashed user credentials over SMB using spearphishing attachments with external resource links and by modifying .LNK file icon resources to collect credentials from virtualized systems.

[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used various types of scripting to perform operations, including Python and batch scripts. The group was observed installing Python 2.7 on a victim.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) has performed screen captures of victims, including by using a tool, scr.exe (which matched the hash of ScreenUtil).
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used batch scripts to enumerate network information, including information about trusts, zones, and the domain.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) manipulated .lnk files to gather user credentials in conjunction with [Forced Authentication](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1187).
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) deleted many of its files used during operations as part of cleanup, including removing applications and deleting screenshots.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) copied and installed tools for operations once in the victim environment.

[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) commonly created Web shells on victims' publicly accessible email and web servers, which they used to maintain access to a victim network and download additional malicious files.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) dropped and executed tools used for password cracking, including Hydra.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) added the registry value ntdll to the Registry Run key to establish persistence.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used spearphishing with PDF attachments containing malicious links that redirected to credential harvesting websites.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used PowerShell scripts for execution.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used spearphishing with Microsoft Office attachments to target victims.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) added newly created accounts to the administrators group to maintain elevated access.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used SMB over ports 445 or 139 for C2. The group also established encrypted connections over port 443.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used the command query user on victim hosts.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) created a directory named "out" in the user's %AppData% folder and copied files to it.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used VPNs and Outlook Web Access (OWA) to maintain access to victim networks.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) moved laterally via RDP.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) used batch scripts to enumerate users in the victim environment.
[Dragonfly 2.0](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0074) compressed data into .zip files prior to exfiltrating it.
